  3. Your Rights and Appeals

If you disagree with a decision about your child's SEND support, you have legal rights. This page explains your options, from informal resolution through to formal appeals.

You have the right to challenge decisions

The law gives parents and young people clear rights in the SEND process. If you think a decision is wrong, you can challenge it. There are several ways to do this, and you do not have to pay for most of them.

SENDIASS can help you at every stage. Their advice is free and confidential. Contact SENDIASS

Your options if you disagree

There are several ways to resolve disagreements, from the least formal to the most formal:

1. Talk to the SEND team

Often, issues can be resolved by speaking directly with the person handling your child's case. Ask questions, explain your concerns, and ask for a written response if needed.

2. Disagreement resolution

A voluntary process to resolve issues without going to tribunal. The council must commission and publicise this service. It is free and both sides agree to take part.

3. Mediation

A meeting with an independent mediator to try to reach agreement. For most tribunal appeals, you must contact a mediation adviser first (even if you decide not to go through mediation).

4. SEND Tribunal

A formal legal process where an independent panel reviews the council's decision. The tribunal can order the council to change its decision.

5. Complaints procedure

If you are unhappy with how the process was handled (rather than the decision itself), you can complain through the council's complaints procedure.

The SEND Tribunal

The First-tier Tribunal (Special Educational Needs and Disability) is an independent legal body that hears appeals about SEND decisions. It is free to register an appeal.

What you can appeal

  • a refusal to carry out an EHC needs assessment
  • a refusal to issue an EHC plan after assessment
  • the contents of your child's EHC plan (Sections B, F and I)
  • a decision to cease (end) an EHC plan
  • a refusal to change an EHC plan after annual review
  • disability discrimination in schools

Who can appeal

  • Parents of children under 16
  • Young people aged 16 and over, in their own name

Time limits

You have 2 months from the date of the decision letter to register your appeal, or 1 month from the date of the mediation certificate, whichever is later.

Before you appeal

For most appeals, you must first contact a mediation adviser. They will issue a certificate confirming you have been given mediation information. You do not have to go through mediation itself — just contact the adviser to get the certificate.

Exception: If you are only appealing about the school named in Section I of the plan, you do not need to contact a mediation adviser first.

Mediation

Mediation is a meeting with an independent, trained mediator. It gives you and the council a chance to discuss the issues and try to reach agreement without going to tribunal.

Key things to know about mediation:

  • it is free
  • it is voluntary — you can choose not to go through mediation and still appeal to tribunal
  • it must be arranged within 30 days of your request
  • it does not affect your right to appeal — you can still go to tribunal if mediation does not resolve the issue

Making a complaint

If you are unhappy with how the SEND process was handled (for example, delays, poor communication, or not following proper procedures), you can use the council's complaints procedure.

If your complaint is not resolved, you can escalate it to the Local Government and Social Care Ombudsman (LGSCO). The Ombudsman investigates complaints about councils and can recommend remedies.

Visit the LGSCO website

Judicial review

In rare cases, you may be able to challenge a council decision through judicial review in the High Court. This is where the decision was unlawful, not just one you disagree with.

Judicial review is a complex legal process with significant cost implications. You should get specialist legal advice before considering this route.

Free help available

SENDIASS can help you understand your options and prepare for mediation or tribunal — at no cost.

Contact SENDIASS
